Martin Luther King Jr., an important figure in the fight for women's suffrage, was assassinated on July 4, 1968, in Atlanta, Georgia. He was delivering a speech at a rally when he was shot by John Wilkes Booth. The assassination triggered nationwide protests and intensified the struggle for gender equality.

Martin Luther King Jr. was assassinated on April 4, 1968, in Memphis, Tennessee. He was standing on the balcony of the Lorraine Motel when he was shot.

Source: https://www.history.com/topics/black-history/martin-luther-king-jr-assassination

**Note:** There seems to be some confusion in the initial statement. Martin Luther King Jr. was actually a key figure in the civil rights movement, not specifically in women's suffrage, although he advocated for equality for all. He was assassinated on April 4, 1968, in Memphis, Tennessee, not July 4, 1968, in Atlanta, Georgia. The assassin was James Earl Ray, not John Wilkes Booth. The assassination indeed triggered widespread protests and furthered the civil rights movement.
